title: Explanation to the prisoner
description: We are going to decide whether it is safe for you to share a cell with someone else.  Most people share cells in this prison.  So it is important that we know as much as possible about you to help us make the best decision.  I have some information about you already and I also have some questions.  THe information you give me will be recorded and may be used by other staff in the prison to support you and make sure you and others are safe. Do you have any concerns about sharing a cell?

title: Prisoner Violence in Prison Estimator (Viper)
description:
The Violence in Prison Estimator (Viper) measures that the likelihood to be the perpetrator of violence in the next 6 months. It's autogenerated using....
(content here is dynamic based on scenario -  first timer, high viper score, medium / low viper score)
(high risk scenario)To the officer: “From what we know from the prisoner’s case files and other information about his/her offence, sentence and previous time and behavior in prison, he/she shares a lot of characteristics with people who have been violent in prisons in the past and therefore falls into the ‘higher risk of violence’ category. As a result, this prisoner should be allocated a single cell.”
To describe to the prisoner: “From what we know from your case files and other information about your offence, sentence and previous time and behavior in prison, we think that it’s safer for you to have a single cell. This is because you are similar in a number of ways to people who have been violent in prisons in the past. We’re not saying you will be violent, but for the sake of safety, across the estate, people who fall into this higher risk of prison violence’ category are given single cells.

title: Prisoner self assessment
description: Do you think you might hurt someone if you share a cell with them?

aside.title: Why is this important?
aside.description: Even if no other risk factors are present, if someone is stating that they intend to harm a cell mate we have to take this seriously and they must be allocated a single cell.

title: Prisoner Vulnerability
description:
Types of questions to ask:
Do you think you might be hurt if you share a cell?
Have you been hurt or threatened in prison before?
Do you owe money to anyone in this prison?
Is there any other reason why someone might hurt you here?

aside.title: Why is this important?
aside.description:
Research on prison violence tells us that people who are more vulnerable to victimisation in prison are also more likely to be violent in prison. This might be because they feel they have to defend themselves, or find themselves in volatile situations, or it might be because repeated victimisation is associated with mental health and behavioral problems, which can sometimes lead to violence.
If you consider the person to be at risk of harm if they share a cell with someone, then this will result in a recommendation of single cell allocation.

title: Gang Affiliation
description:
Types of questions to ask:
Are you in a gang?
Are there any gangs or people you need to stay away from while you’re in here?
If you see someone from a rival gang, what might happen?

aside.title: Why is this important?
aside.description:
Research tells us that people who are part of gangs when they come to prison or who join gangs when in prison are more likely than other prisoners to be violent during their stay. For this reason, it is important to establish whether or not the person is part of a gang.
If this is the only risk factor present for someone, then it doesn’t mean they have to have a single cell, but if other risk factors become relevant, they might be recommended a single cell.

title: Drug misuse
description:
Question to ask:-
Have you used any drugs in the last month?

aside.title: Why is this important?
aside.description:
Research on prison violence tells us that people who have been recently using drugs are more likely than other prisoners to be violent in prison. There are lots of possible reasons for this. For some it might be involvement in the illicit economy, dealing or getting into debt. For others, their drug use might affect their thinking, making them more suspicious and hostile, or might stop them thinking things through and controlling their impulses. Violence can also result from drug-induced psychosis.
As lots of people who come to prison take or have recently taken drugs, on its own this risk factor will not lead to a single cell allocation. However, when this is combined with other risk factors, it can lead to the recommendation that it would be safer to house them in a single cell.

title: Prejudices and hostile views
description:
Question to ask:-
Are there any particular types of people (e.g., of different age, race, religion, gender identity, offence history or people with addictions), that you would find it difficult to share with?

aside.title: Why is this important?
aside.description: We have a duty of care to keep people safe from discrimination. If someone has hostile attitudes towards a particular group, this needs to be noted, to keep others safe. However, hostile attitudes on their own don’t mean that someone will automatically be given a single cell. They may be safe to share with a range of other people, and this will be taken into account in the final recommendation.

title: Other reasons
description: Is there any other reason to think that this person is not safe to share a cell?

aside.title: Why is this important?
aside.description: If there is any other information from case records or from the prisoner, that raises concerns that he/she might be violent towards a cell mate, then note it here.
